alert.note: Alert for Johnson; Washington; Wilkinson (Georgia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 31 at 4:03AM EDT until April 02 at 5:36AM EDT by NWS Atlanta
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia... Flint River at GA 26 near Montezuma affecting Dooly, Sumter and Macon Counties. Ocmulgee River at US 341 at Hawkinsville affecting Pulaski and Bleckley Counties. Ocmulgee River at Abbeville affecting Wilcox, Dodge and Telfair Counties. Oconee River at Dublin affecting Washington, Johnson, Laurens and Wilkinson Counties. Oconee River near Oconee affecting Washington, Johnson and Wilkinson Counties. For the Flint River Basin...including Lovejoy, Peachtree City, Fayetteville, Americus, Peachtree City, Woolsey, Sharpsburg, Peachtree City, Peachtree City, Senoia, Griffin, Griffin, Orchard Hill, Molena, Thomaston, Carsonville, Montezuma, Byromville...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Ocmulgee River Basin...including Jackson, Griffin, Juliette, Juliette, Dames Ferry, Macon, Macon, Hawkinsville, Byron, Clinchfield, Hawkinsville, Abbeville, McRae, Scotland, Lumber City... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Oconee River Basin...including Penfield, Milledgeville, Oconee, Oconee, McIntyre, Irwinton, Oconee, Dublin, Mount Vernon... Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY SUNDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring. * WHERE...Oconee River near Oconee. * WHEN...Until early Sunday morning. * IMPACTS...At 21 feet, Moderate flooding begins. The dirt parking lot by the Old Balls Ferry Road boat ramp is under one to three feet of water. The end of Old Balls Ferry Road begins to flood. Flooding continues and spreads further into the woodlands near the river. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:45 AM EDT Friday the stage was 20.8 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:45 AM EDT Friday was 24.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 21 feet this morning. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 17 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 20.6 feet on 09/20/2020. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at weather.gov/atlanta.
